Parameters
bbasic container struct bufrdeco

int bufrdeco_increase_data_array ( struct bufrdeco_subset_sequence_data *  s)

doubles the allocated space for a struct bufrdeco_subset_sequence_data whenever is posible

Parameters
spointer to source struct bufrdeco_subset_sequence_data

The amount of data in a bufr must be huge. In a first moment, the dimension of a sequence of structs bufr_atom_data is BUFR_NMAXSEQ but may be increased. This function task is try to double the allocated dimension and reallocate it.

Return 0 when success, otherwise return 1 and the struct is unmodified

int bufrdeco_parse_compressed ( struct bufrdeco_compressed_data_references *  r,
struct bufrdeco *  b 
)

Parse a compressed data bufr.

Parameters
rpointer to a struct bufrdeco_compressed_data_references where to set the results
bbasic container struct bufrdeco

When a bufr report has compressed data, it is needed to do a first parse step to get references about where to find the data for every descriptor in subsets. This is what this function does. If succeeded the struct r will have all needed data to decode individual subsets.

Also be mind that the descriptors tree have to be already parsed when calling this function

Returns 0 if succeeded, 1 otherwise

int bufrdeco_parse_tree ( struct bufrdeco *  b)

Parse the tree of descriptors without expand the replicators.

Parameters
bPointer to the source struct bufrdeco

This is the user function to parse the descriptor structure of a BUFR report. This is the first task we need to perform after read the bufr report with the aid of bufrdeco_read_bufr function.

At the end we will get an array of structs bufr_sequence defining the tree

A sequence layer is needed when parsing expanded descriptor sec3 and sec4

First bufr_sequence is the sequence of descriptors in sec3 after byte 8. This is a bufr_sequence in level 0.

When a sequence descriptor is found in a layer, the sequence entries found in table D form this descriptor is a son bufr_sequence. This son has then a father and also can have one or more sons. The index level is incremented by one every step it go into decendents.

And so we go in a recursive way up to the end.

If success return 0, if something went wrong return 1

int bufrdeco_read_bufr ( struct bufrdeco *  b,
char *  filename 
)

Read bufr file and does preliminary and first decode pass.

Parameters
bpointer to struct bufrdeco
filenamecomplete path of BUFR file

This function does the folowing tasks:

  • Read the file and checks the marks at the begining and end to see wheter is a BUFR file
  • Init the structs and allocate the needed memory if not done previously
  • Splits and parse the BUFR sections (without expanding descriptors nor parsing data)
  • Reads the needed Table files and store them in memory.

Returns 0 if all is OK, 1 otherwise

< pointer to a memory buffer where we write raw bufr file

61  if ( ( bufrx = ( uint8_t * ) calloc ( 1, st.st_size + 4 ) ) == NULL )
62  {
63  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): cannot alloc memory for file '%s'\n", filename );
64  return 1;
65  }
66  }
67  else
68  {
69  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): '%s' is not a regular file nor symbolic link\n", filename );
70  return 1;
71  }
72 
73  /* Inits bufr struct */
74  if ( ( st.st_size + 4 ) >= BUFR_LEN )
75  {
76  sprintf ( b->error, "File '%s' too large. Consider increase BUFR_LEN\n", filename );
77  free ( ( void * ) bufrx );
78  return 1;
79  }
80 
81  // Open and read the file
82  if ( ( fp = fopen ( filename, "r" ) ) == NULL )
83  {
84  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): cannot open file '%s'\n", filename );
85  free ( ( void * ) bufrx );
86  return 1;
87  }
88 
89  while ( ( aux = fgetc ( fp ) ) != EOF && ( int ) n < st.st_size )
90  bufrx[n++] = ( uint8_t ) aux;
91 
92  // close the file
93  fclose ( fp );
94 
95  // Some fast checks
96  if ( n < 8 )
97  {
98  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): Too few bytes for a bufr\n" );
99  free ( ( void * ) bufrx );
100  return 1;
101  }
102 
103  // check if begins with BUFR
104  if ( bufrx[0] != 'B' || bufrx[1] != 'U' || bufrx[2] != 'F' || bufrx[3] != 'R' )
105  {
106  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): file '%s' does not begin with 'BUFR' chars\n", filename );
107  free ( ( void * ) bufrx );
108  return 1;
109  }
110 
111  // check if end with '7777'
112  if ( bufrx[n - 4] != '7' || bufrx[n - 3] != '7' || bufrx[n - 2] != '7' || bufrx[n - 1] != '7' )
113  {
114  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): file '%s' does not end with '7777' chars\n", filename );
115  free ( ( void * ) bufrx );
116  return 1;
117  }
118 
119  /******************* section 0 *****************************/
120 
121  // we have already checked about begin and end
122 
123  // length of whole message
124  b->sec0.bufr_length = three_bytes_to_uint32 ( &bufrx[4] );
125  // check if length is correct
126  if ( b->sec0.bufr_length != ( uint32_t ) n )
127  {
128  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): file '%s' have %u bytes and it says %u\n", filename,
129  ( uint32_t ) n, b->sec0.bufr_length );
130  free ( ( void * ) bufrx );
131  return 1;
132  }
133 
134  // set bufr edition number
135  b->sec0.edition = bufrx[7];
136 
137  if ( b->sec0.edition < 3 )
138  {
139  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): Bufr edition must be 3 or superior and this file is coded with version %u\n", b->sec0.edition );
140  free ( ( void * ) bufrx );
141  return 1;
142  }
143 
144  // raw
145  memcpy ( &b->sec0.raw[0], &bufrx[0], 8 );
146 
147  /******************* section 1 *****************************/
148  c = &bufrx[8]; // pointer to begin of sec1
149  switch ( b->sec0.edition )
150  {
151  case 3:
152  b->sec1.length = three_bytes_to_uint32 ( c );
153  b->sec1.master = c[3];
154  b->sec1.subcentre = c[4];
155  b->sec1.centre = c[5];
156  b->sec1.update = c[6];
157  b->sec1.options = c[7];
158  b->sec1.category = c[8];
159  b->sec1.subcategory = c[9];
160  b->sec1.subcategory_local = 0; // not in version 3
161  b->sec1.master_version = c[10];
162  b->sec1.master_local = c[11];
163  if ( c[12] > 80 )
164  b->sec1.year = 1900 + c[12];
165  else
166  b->sec1.year = 2900 + c[12];
167  b->sec1.month = c[13];
168  b->sec1.day = c[14];
169  b->sec1.hour = c[15];
170  b->sec1.minute = c[16];
171  b->sec1.second = 0; // not in version 3
172  break;
173  case 4:
174  b->sec1.length = three_bytes_to_uint32 ( c );
175  b->sec1.master = c[3];
176  b->sec1.centre = two_bytes_to_uint32 ( &c[4] );
177  b->sec1.subcentre = two_bytes_to_uint32 ( &c[6] );
178  b->sec1.update = c[8];
179  b->sec1.options = c[9];
180  b->sec1.category = c[10];
181  b->sec1.subcategory = c[11];
182  b->sec1.subcategory_local = c[12];
183  b->sec1.master_version = c[13];
184  b->sec1.master_local = c[14];
185  b->sec1.year = two_bytes_to_uint32 ( &c[15] );
186  b->sec1.month = c[17];
187  b->sec1.day = c[18];
188  b->sec1.hour = c[19];
189  b->sec1.minute = c[20];
190  b->sec1.second = c[21];
191  break;
192  default:
193  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_read_bufr(): This file is coded with version %u and is not supported\n", b->sec0.edition );
194  free ( ( void * ) bufrx );
195  return 1;
196  }
197  memcpy ( b->sec1.raw, c, b->sec1.length ); // raw data
198  c += b->sec1.length;
199  //print_sec1_info(b);
200 
201  /******************* section 2 (Optional) ******************/
202  if ( b->sec1.options & 0x80 )
203  {
204  b->sec2.length = three_bytes_to_uint32 ( c );
205  memcpy ( b->sec2.raw, c, b->sec2.length );
206  c += b->sec2.length;
207  }
208 
209  /******************* section 3 *****************************/
210  b->sec3.length = three_bytes_to_uint32 ( c );
211  b->sec3.subsets = two_bytes_to_uint32 ( &c[4] );
212  if ( c[6] & 0x80 )
213  b->sec3.observed = 1;
214  else
215  b->sec3.observed = 0;
216  if ( c[6] & 0x40 )
217  b->sec3.compressed = 1;
218  else
219  b->sec3.compressed = 0;
220 
221  // loop of unexpanded descriptors
222  for ( ix = 7, ud = 0; ix < b->sec3.length && ud < BUFR_LEN_UNEXPANDED_DESCRIPTOR; ix += 2 )
223  {
224  two_bytes_to_descriptor ( &b->sec3.unexpanded[ud], &c[ix] );
225  if ( b->sec3.unexpanded[ud].f || b->sec3.unexpanded[ud].x || b->sec3.unexpanded[ud].y )
226  ud++;
227  }
228  b->sec3.ndesc = ud;
229  memcpy ( b->sec3.raw, c, b->sec3.length );
230  c += b->sec3.length;
231 
232  /******************* section 4 *****************************/
233  b->sec4.length = three_bytes_to_uint32 ( c );
234  // we copy 4 byte more without danger because of latest '7777' and to use fastest exctracting bits algorithm
235  memcpy ( b->sec4.raw, c, b->sec4.length + 4 );
236 
237  b->sec4.bit_offset = 32; // the first bit in byte 4
238  free ( ( void * ) bufrx );
239 
240  if ( b->mask & BUFRDECO_USE_ECMWF_TABLES )
241  {
242  if ( bufr_read_tables_ecmwf ( b, NULL ) )
243  {
244  return 1;
245  }
246  }
247  else
248  {
249  if ( bufr_read_tables_wmo ( b, NULL ) )
250  {
251  return 1;
252  }
253  }
254  return 0;
255 }

int bufrdeco_substitute_tables ( struct bufr_tables **  replaced,
struct bufr_tables *  source,
struct bufrdeco *  b 
)

substitute an struct bufr_tables into a struct bufrdeco

Parameters
replacedPointer where to set the replaced pointer
sourcePointer to a struct bufr_tables
bpointer to the container basic struct bufrdeco

Remember that the struct bufr_tables used in bufrdeco library is the one which pointer is in struct bufrdeco . To avoid problems the struct must be initialized before substituted in this fucntion. Both source and replaced structs are not modified.

This is useful if we do not want to read and parse tables again if the caller has a pool of already readed tables.

307  if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &ival, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), 6 ) == 0 )
308  {
309  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get 6 bits for inc_bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
310  return 1;
311  }
312  // Here is supossed that all subsets will have the same reference change,
313  // so inc_bits must be 0 and no inc data should be present
314  if ( ival )
315  {
316  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Bad format for compressed data when changing reference from '%s'\n", d->c );
317  return 1;
318  }
319  r->ref0 = 0; // here we also assume that ref0 = 0
320  r->inc_bits = 0;
321  return 0;
322  }
323 
324  if ( strstr ( r->unit, "CCITT" ) != NULL)
325  {
326  if ( b->state.fixed_ccitt != 0 ) // can be changed by 2 08 YYY operator
327  r->bits = 8 * b->state.fixed_ccitt;
328 
329  if ( get_bits_as_char_array ( r->cref0, &r->has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), r->bits ) == 0 )
330  {
331  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get uchars from '%s'\n", d->c );
332  return 1;
333  }
334  // extracting inc_bits from next 6 bits
335  if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &ival, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), 6 ) == 0 )
336  {
337  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get 6 bits for inc_bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
338  return 1;
339  }
340  r->inc_bits = ival;
341  r->ref0 = 0;
342 
343  // Set the bit_offset
344  b->state.bit_offset += r->inc_bits * 8 * b->sec3.subsets;
345 
346  return 0;
347  }
348 
349  // is a numeric field, i.e, a data value, a flag code or a code
350  if ( mode ) // case of associated field
351  {
352  if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &r->ref0, &r->has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), b->state.assoc_bits ) == 0 )
353  {
354  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get associated bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
355  return 1;
356  }
357  // patch for delayed descriptor: it allways have data
358  if ( d->x == 31 )
359  r->has_data = 1;
360  }
361  else // case of data
362  {
363  if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &r->ref0, &r->has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), r->bits ) == 0 )
364  {
365  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get the data bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
366  return 1;
367  }
368  // patch for delayed descriptor: it allways have data
369  if ( d->x == 31 )
370  r->has_data = 1;
371  }
372 
373  // extracting inc_bits from next 6 bits
374  if ( get_bits_as_uint32_t ( &ival, &has_data, &b->sec4.raw[4], & ( b->state.bit_offset ), 6 ) == 0 )
375  {
376  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Cannot get 6 bits for inc_bits from '%s'\n", d->c );
377  return 1;
378  }
379  r->inc_bits = ival;
380 
381  // if is a delayed descriptor then inc_bits MUST be 0.
382  if ( is_a_delayed_descriptor ( d ) && r->inc_bits )
383  {
384  sprintf ( b->error, "bufrdeco_tableb_compressed(): Found a delayed descriptor with inc_bits != 0\n" );
385  return 1;
386  }
387  // Set the bit_offset
388  b->state.bit_offset += r->inc_bits * b->sec3.subsets;
389 
390  return 0;
391 }

int get_ecmwf_tablenames ( struct bufrdeco *  b,
const char *  bufrtables_dir 
)

Get the complete pathnames for EMCWF table files needed by a bufr message.

Parameters
bufrtables_dirstring with path to bufr file tables dir
bpointer for a struct bufrdeco

In ECMWF library the name of a table file is Kssswwwwwxxxxxyyyzzz.TXT , where

  • K - type of table, i.e, 'B', 'C', or 'D'
  • sss - Master table number (zero for WMO meteorological tables)
  • wwwww - Originating sub-centre
  • xxxxx - Originating centre
  • yyy - Version number of master table used
  • zzz - Version number of local table used

int get_wmo_tablenames ( struct bufrdeco *  b,
const char *  bufrtables_dir 
)

Get the complete pathnames for WMO csv table files needed by a bufr message.

Parameters
bufrtables_dirstring with path to bufr file tables dir
bpointer for a struct bufrdeco

For WMO files this format is adopted BUFR_XX_Y_Z_TableB_en for table B BUFR_XX_Y_Z_CodeFlag for Code table and Flag table. This is equivalent to table C in ECMWF package BUFR_XX_Y_Z_TableD_en for table D

XX is the Version number of master table used Y is the revision (currently ignored) Z is minor revision (currently ignored)
